Interesting idea... I do see the sense in having the dragon head be the trophy... however, I believe if you kill it more than once, you could still get more of them. Also the dragon egg hatching seems a little bit ambitious for now.
I said that you'll get only one head, just like how the current egg is. And also, You don't really need to make the baby dragon a mini boss. It could just be just as strong as a phantom.

This is a brilliant idea, however removing the dragon head that generates on the front of the ships doesn't really fit imo. The heads signify that the civilizations that have built those cities and ships must have slain dozens of dragons, leaving the species almost extinct. Adding the egg to the ship like you said would make sense tho, considering the fact that killing the dragon gives you an egg as well.

On top of that idea, maybe players could tame the baby dragons and not just kill them? You only really need one elytra on a single player world, and on multiplayer it would still work, considering that end ships are infinitely generated.
How would this affect the people who already got the egg/dragon head?

I love this idea! I think figs should be crafted with wheat and sugar to make fig newtons, which could heal eight hunger. There could be other recipes made with figs, but this is just one I could think of off the top of my head.

Clarified subject to help search results.

Thanks for your contribution.
I like it, however, stacking to 16 is a bit much, allow it to stack to 4, which may be a bit more balenced. Also, when throwing it should do less damage, to prevent people from spamming them.

@Some Animal

Thank you for your comment.

There would be a cooldown involved with throwing, which I would suggest should be 1/2-3/4 that of using a trident. However, I take your point about reducing the damage, which I think makes sense, so I would propose throwing deals 2HP (1 heart) less damage than wielding. On the stacking, once a cooldown is introduced there is no real difference between them and a bow, so I personally don't feel that 16 in unreasonable. However, I do agree that people shouldn't just be able to spam them, so if the cooldown isn't enough to prevent this then maye reducing the stack size is worthwhile.

You are right, a cooldown would solve the problem, however, I saw a nice post by Machu Picchu saying that potions and soups should stack to four, and seeing this made me think in the same vein, but I think that being able to spam 4 without having a cool down would make a new playstyle. Also, the twin blade is more expensive than a sword. By design?

@Some Animal

Yes, the cost is deliberately more than a sword. Partially.

If I'm honest part of the cost is just because I wanted to make the crafting recipe vaguely resemble what I had in mind. But yes, I was aware at the time and factored that in. I actually had two thoughts on that myself.

1) Multiple twinblades. The crafting recipe could actually make 4 twinblades instead of 1, so therefore they would actually be individually cheaper than swords.

2) Their relative power. Whilst they do -1/-2 damage compared to a sword, the fact that they can be thrown makes them more versatile. I also intended them to have a different function to the sword, which is represented by their 'slicing' ability to ignore armour (which would prove interesting when introduced to a PvP server/minigame) and their unique enchantments, in particular 'grounding', making them the first real weapon aimed at flying mobs.

Effectively I envision the twinblade as an alternative to arrows. For me at least, making arrows is an excessively exhausting process, requiring me to kill a chicken and dig through lots of gravel. So to have an alternative would be appealing, despite the relative expense of a weapon. In addition, the stackability and faster-than-arrow cooldown make them a potentially lethal ranged weapon.

At first I didn't read the enchantments, but now I have, and I have two problems. One being lethality, doing poison is a bit much, something you would think would be a potion effect. Grounding is good, but perhaps it should instead pull the mob to the ground so one may hit it, as smite means to break the undead mobs bones, and sharpness is to cut living mobs' flesh bane of Arthropods hits the exoskeleton, so it doesn't make sense for flying mobs, with various different physiologies to be effected by one same enchantment.

@Some Animal

I take your point on Lethality basically being a potion. I don't have a particularly strong attachment to the idea, so I am happy for it to be forgotten.

I actually prefer your idea for grounding to my own, but it should still do some minor damage (maybe 1HP per 8 blocks or something) upon pulling the mob to the ground (I think it's reasonable to assume suddenly plummeting out of the sky would hurt. There could also be a 'grounded' status effect that prevents mobs from flying/jumping for 3 seconds upon hitting the ground. Higher level enchantments could therefore increase the speed of the fall and the length of the 'grounded' effect.

I’m sorry it took me so long to see this. This is actually a very intriguing idea. Basically an axe head on each end? I’d definitely like to see this come to the game. Perhaps it’ll be possible to put it in an add on when they add custom 3D weapon support.

How many fish could you put in it?

Thank you for explaining this idea! I too want an aquarium option available.

What do you want done?

Like the OP said, an aquarium block would be great! Or at least offer more fish species in the game (both fresh and salt) to give more variety. Perhaps add a function to gravel so when you use the crafting table you can dye the gravel, add glow ink if you want flourescent gravel, to make an aquarium substrate. Or maybe the Totem of Undying could be put into a fishtank (since some of the totems look like cute fishtank decorations).

Why do you want something done?

Minecraft is a limitless game. Not only can we take great adventures in the game, but we can also make homes that some ofus cannot have in the real world. Getting to even have an aquarium is not an option for some of us.

How do you want something done?

As was aforementioned, having another crafting option for gravel would be great, perhaps an aquarium block type, and maybe even some more fish species (both fresh and salt).
You should talk about what you can use the fruit for also.

This is such a great idea! I think it’d be a cool thing for players to learn that the baobab tree indeed has a fruit, and perhaps in the future we can try implementing more “weird” fruits! I wonder if the MC developers would ever consider looking more into fruits that most people don’t know about, or fruits that are at risk of extinction. Fruits are so interesting and I wish that Minecraft would spark that curiosity for people who don’t know about just how many cool fruits exist!
sounds good to me.

Yea I think this would be really cool and game changing if it got added, but one thing I'd like to mention is that it would be kinda op if they just lasted forever, so they would probably need to have limited use, basically, a potion effect bar just like a durability bar that went down as the effect got used, so stuff tipped with potion of strength would lose potion as you hit mobs with it, armor with potion of turtle master would lose potion as you got hit, stuff with potion of slow falling would lose potion as you fall, etc. Also, it would probably make sense to only let certain things get certain enchantment, as it would make no sense to have night vision on boots or jump boost on a hoe.

I would like to inform you of a way to make your tnt arrows.

 

you place one command block that is impulse unconditional and needs redstone. enter this command:

/give @a tipped_arrow{CustomPotionColor:16711680,display:{Name:'[{"text":"TNT Arrow","italic":false,"color":"red","bold":true}]',Lore:['[{"text":"Boom."}]']}} 64

then place a button on that command block. It will give you your special arrows.

to make the arrows work place two repeating unconditional and always active command blocks.

in one of them enter:

/execute at @e[type=arrow,nbt={Color:16711680,inGround:1b}] run summon creeper ~ ~ ~ {Fuse:0,ingnite:1b}

and in the other one enter this

/execute at @e[type=arrow,nbt={Color:16711680,inGround:1b}] run summon creeper ~ ~ ~ {Fuse:0,ingnite:1b}

also if you don't know how to get command blocks

press"t" and then enter

/give @p command_block

place it and right click while in creative with cheats on to open it. adjust the settings and copy and paste the commands. :)

The brown ones do but cannot be used as an effective light source, making a room mob proof.

Good point, i did mention that it would function like sea pickles but did not specify how, a toggleable light source. They could have a dark purple or blue texture to contrast the brown and red mushrooms already in game avoiding green since the pickles already are greeen. Orange and yellow could look too close to the current brown or red mushrooms or netherwart. The mushrooms could stack up to 4 in a single block space, like turtle eggs and pickles.
